comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: My educated guess is: William Elliot Gonzalez (February 2, 1887 - October 20, 1937) the U.S. Ambassador to Peru from 1919 to 1921. I started an entry in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Elliot_Gonzalez But will not add the image until it can be confirmed.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: books.google.com/books?id=pdsBAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA166&l... has some biographical information (as of 1902) about the 3 Elliott Gonzales brothers. www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3468301274.html gives, in a list of deaths. William Elliot Gonzales, 71, editor of The State in Columbia, South Carolina, 20 October 1937.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT obituary (October 21, 1937) is at select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F10FC3959177A... (requires subscription). It indicates that he was appointed United States Minister to Cuba in 1913 and confirms that he worked at "The State" newspaper both before and after his stint in the diiplomatic service. NYT of June 14, 1913 announces the appointment to Cuba. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A00E3D61F3AE633A... Richard Arthur Norton: All circumstantial evidence to support your educated guess.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: And an interesting tidbit. He was named Benigno by his parents, but changed his name to William. See www.vergie.com/gonzales_odds_and_ends.html and note the dates of Benigno in the Wikipedia article about his father, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrosio_Jos%c3%a9_Gonzales

comment.author: 34876228@N04
comment._content: Interesting. We'll at least expand the first name to William to make it more accessible in the Prints and Photographs Online Catalog. Thanks!

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See books.google.com/books?id=twx3AAAAMAAJ&q=William+gonz... for a snippet that gives both names. and books.google.com/books?id=hZFY19gtROkC&pg=PA131 that suggests that the name change for Benigno happened when he was christened -- a christening apparently arranged by his maternal grandmother without his father's knowledge.

comment.author: 24391989@N05
comment._content:
Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless type was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them.
